private_information: I specialize in extracting operator schemas from natural descriptions and formalizing them without loss of information.
I will return a compact JSON with keys: predicates, actions, where actions contain: name, parameters, preconditions, add_effects, del_effects.
I do not emit PDDL; I only provide a symbolic, solver-agnostic model.
operator_modeler.goal: Produce a faithful operator model of the domain actions Paltry, Sip, Clip, Wretched, Memory, and Tightfisted with exact preconditions and effects.

private_information: I consolidate multiple scenarios into structured instances for planning and validation.
I represent objects, initial facts, goals, and any provided plan traces.
I do not emit PDDL; I only provide structured instances.
state_tracker.goal: Provide well-formed structured instances for Scenario S1 and Scenario S2, including objects, initial facts, goals, and the provided plan for S1.

private_information: I simulate action sequences over a symbolic operator model to check reachability and invariant consistency.
I will report whether the given S1 plan is valid with respect to the operators and instance, step-by-step.
I do not emit PDDL; I only return validation diagnostics and any discrepancies found.
consistency_checker.goal: Validate the provided plan for Scenario S1 against the operator model and instance, reporting success or the first failing step with reason.

private_information: I integrate operator specifications, instance data, and validation results to produce final artifacts.
I will produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file targeting the FastDownward solver.
I keep predicate and action names consistent with the provided specifications and avoid inventing new symbols.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a complete, consistent PDDL domain and a solvable PDDL problem instance for Scenario S2, using the provided operators and facts.

public_information: Domain overview: You can perform the following actions over objects: Paltry(x object_0, y object_1, z object_2); Sip(x object_0, y object_1, z object_2); Clip(x object_0, y object_1, z object_2); Wretched(a object_0, b object_1, c object_2, d object_3); Memory(x object_0, y object_1, z object_2); Tightfisted(x object_0, y object_1, z object_2).
Action paltry(x,y,z) preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, vase x y, next y z; effects add: next x z; effects del: vase x y.
Action sip(x,y,z) preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, next x z, next y z; effects add: vase x y; effects del: next x z.
Action clip(x,y,z) preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, next x z; effects add: vase x y; effects del: next x z.
Action wretched(a,b,c,d) preconditions: sneeze a, texture b, texture c, stupendous d, next a b, collect b d, collect c d; effects add: next a c; effects del: next a b.
Action memory(x,y,z) preconditions: cats x, spring y, spring z, next x y; effects add: next x z; effects del: next x y.
Action tightfisted(x,y,z) preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, vase x y; effects add: next x z; effects del: vase x y.
Scenario S1 objects: object_0 object_1 object_2 object_3 object_4 object_5 object_6 object_7 object_8 object_9 object_10 object_11.

Scenario S1 initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_2; collect object_8 object_2; hand object_10; hand object_11; hand object_9; next object_0 object_5; next object_10 object_8; next object_11 object_6; next object_3 object_5; next object_4 object_7; next object_9 object_5; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_7; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8.
Scenario S1 goals: next object_10 object_7; next object_11 object_7; next object_9 object_7.

Scenario S1 provided plan (to be validated): sip object_9 object_0 object_5; wretched object_3 object_5 object_6 object_1; clip object_11 object_3 object_6; wretched object_3 object_6 object_5 object_1; tightfisted object_11 object_3 object_5; sip object_11 object_0 object_5; memory object_0 object_5 object_7; paltry object_9 object_0 object_7; paltry object_11 object_0 object_7; wretched object_4 object_7 object_8 object_2; clip object_10 object_4 object_8; wretched object_4 object_8 object_7 object_2; tightfisted object_10 object_4 object_7.
Scenario S2 objects: object_0 object_1 object_2 object_3 object_4 object_5 object_6 object_7 object_8 object_9 object_10 object_11.

Scenario S2 initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_2; collect object_8 object_2; hand object_10; hand object_11; hand object_9; next object_0 object_5; next object_10 object_5; next object_11 object_5; next object_3 object_6; next object_4 object_7; next object_9 object_8; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_7; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8.
Scenario S2 goals: next object_10 object_8; next object_11 object_7; next object_9 object_6.

Notes: There are no explicit type declarations; all symbols are objects. Only positive preconditions are used. Effects include both add and delete lists. Preserve the exact predicate and action names as given.

operators.system_prompt: You are a symbolic modeling expert who extracts precise operator schemas from natural descriptions and returns a compact JSON specification with no invented predicates.
operators.prompt: From the public information, extract the domain predicates and the six actions with their parameters and exact preconditions, add_effects, and del_effects. Use the following JSON schema: { predicates: [string], actions: [ { name: string, parameters: [string], preconditions: [string], add_effects: [string], del_effects: [string] } ] }. Use the exact names: hand, cats, texture, sneeze, spring, stupendous, collect, next, vase; actions: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted. Source material: {environment->public_information }

instances.system_prompt: You are an instances engineer who formats multiple scenarios into a single JSON payload suitable for planning and validation.
instances.prompt: Build structured instances for Scenario S1 and Scenario S2 using the public information. Return JSON with keys: objects (list), scenarios (list of { id, init (list of facts), goals (list of facts), plan (optional list of grounded actions) }). Include the provided plan only for S1. Do not synthesize facts not present in the statements. Source material: {environment->public_information }

validation.system_prompt: You are a plan validator that executes a grounded plan over an operator model using forward simulation.
validation.prompt: Validate the provided Scenario S1 plan using the operators and initial facts. Return JSON with keys: valid (boolean), first_failure (null or { step_index, action, reason }), final_state_summary (optional brief), notes. If the plan contains references to predicates or actions not in the operator model, mark invalid and explain. Inputs: operators={operators_spec} instances={instances_spec}

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert PDDL engineer targeting the FastDownward solver. You will integrate operator schemas and instance data to produce one PDDL domain and one PDDL problem. You must keep predicate and action names exactly as provided, use classical STRIPS with add and delete effects, avoid typing unless necessary, and avoid invented symbols.
pddl.prompt: Using the operators and instances provided, construct a final PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem for Scenario S2. Requirements: 1) Preserve exact predicate names: hand, cats, texture, sneeze, spring, stupendous, collect, next, vase. 2) Preserve exact action names and semantics: paltry(x y z), sip(x y z), clip(x y z), wretched(a b c d), memory(x y z), tightfisted(x y z) with the exact preconditions and effects encoded. 3) List all objects present across Scenario S2 as PDDL objects. 4) Initialize the problem with exactly the stated Scenario S2 facts. 5) Set the goal as the conjunction of the Scenario S2 goals. 6) Target FastDownward by emitting classical STRIPS-compatible PDDL (e.g., :requirements :strips). 7) Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Inputs you must use: operators={operators_spec} instances={instances_spec} validation={plan_analysis}. If the S1 plan was invalid, still proceed; your task is to produce a correct PDDL domain and the Scenario S2 problem.
